dict.string: Blindfold yourself. Think about a story you've been trying to write. Start with a blank page. Don't stop until it's all out.
2. Interrogation
Rewrite a story from an author you hate, word-for-word.
3. Playlist
Make a playlist. Better yet, use a playlist you’ve already made. That is your plotline.
4. Songs Are People, Too
Let your favorite song’s structure’s—intro-verse-chorus-verse-bridge-etc.—inform the story you’re working on.
5. Criminal
Steal a story. Change elements and lines until it’s unrecognizable.
Call your phone and leave a voicemail about a memory of a beautiful evening with a family member. Let yourself go. Ramble a little. Transcribe the message.
7. The Dark
Your main character is struck blind. Use their other senses.
Create two fake email address for two different characters. They've just started dating long distance. Write 10 emails back and forth.
9. Steam
Open the book nearest to you to page 69. The first sentence is the first sentence of your piece, and it's a steamy piece.
Write with a tool that you do not typically use. For instance, if you write with a pen, use your phone. If you use a computer, write on a wall. Get weird.
Write a list of your 3 favorite places in the world. What do they sound like?
Think of an adjective. Got it? That's your character's first name. His last name is Johnson and he owes people money.
Write the piece your father would write.
14. Democracy
Write a story with two endings. Make your friends read it and vote. The winner is the ending.
Send a very emotional Facebook message to an old, old friend. (You can just tell them it was a mistake later.) Their response is the opening paragraph of your new work.
16. Time to Kill
The next time you’re on the can, type out the most memorable image of your childhood.
Get drunk. Read a section of a religious text. Eviscerate it by dawn.
18. Parents
Write your parents’ love story, beginning to present. 500 words.
19. Taxes
Do your character’s taxes.
20. Conversation
Make sure that her necklace isn’t a symbol for her childhood.
21. Power
Print out what you’re working on and give it to someone you trust. Delete all copies from your computer. If your friend thinks it’s good, re-type it. If they think it’s bad, have them burn it.
Get naked. Write at your kitchen table.
23. The Locked Room
Grab a magazine. Write a long short story using only the elements contained within that magazine.
Write some flash fiction on your lover's back. Voltaire did it!
Take your worst fear. Write a short story where you confront it. Rewrite this story once a year for 20 years. Never reread.
26. Doctor
Pay a friend to inspect everything you've ever written. Get their diagnosis.
Record your latest piece of writing, save that recording as your alarm. Upon waking, write for a half an hour while laying in bed.
Give up today. You’ll get at it tomorrow.
29. Radio Burroughs
Put your radio on scan, write down as many words as you catch in three minutes. Include all these phrases in a short story
Write a story, footnotes first.
31. OK Character
Create a character sketch, now create a profile for this character on a dating website.
32. Mistakes
Print out your story. Lay the pages, shuffled, on the floor. Remove 25% of the pages at random and retype it.
Take a twenty dollar bill, write a poem that you'd pay twenty dollars to read on the bill. Donate it.
Imagine the life you’re living right now is Heaven. Set a story in Hell.
Rationalize a broken commandment.
36. Research
If you could travel back in time, what moment in history would you visit? Got it? Set a story there. And do your damn research!
37. Fog of Night
Third person ignorant (as in anti-omniscient) narrator. No dialogue. 1,000 words by daybreak.
Worst case scenario in media res. Not a single line of exposition!
Take a completed draft. Change the main character's race. Rewrite accordingly.
Never kill your darlings. Add, add, add until your darlings are no longer darlings.
41. Worth It
Take a photograph, any photograph. Write a grammatically correct sentence that is exactly 1,000 words long inspired by the photo.
Rewatch your favorite movie on mute. Write a poem.
Dress in your favorite outfit. Write in public.
Write a story about your richest friend. Name that character Y. Write their undoing in the form of a newspaper article.
45. Eavesdrop
Take notes in your phone. Use only the dialogue you overhear in your next story.
Type "sex scandal" into a newspapers search engine. Compound and fictionalization the first and ninety ninth article.
47. Found in Translation

Write the first paragraph of a short story. Copy and paste into an online translator. Translate to a Russian. Russian to Japanese. Japanese to Swahili. Swahili to English. Write the rest of the story in the syntax of the translated paragraph.
Mythologize a current event.
49. All Grown Up
What was your dream job as a child? Set your next short story in that profession.
Stop what you are doing and write a story where you stop what you are doing, empty your bank account and drive away. Write as far as the money gets you.
51. Stargazing & Stamina
Plan a night to write all night. Only get up to go to the bathroom and refresh your drink. Food at 3AM. When you see the dawn, go to bed.
Pick an important day in your life. Write that day from the perspective of your significant other. If you don't have a significant other, choose the person with whom you shared that day.
Copy and paste a recent text conversation you had with a friend. That is your opening dialogue.
54. Devil in the Details
Think back to the last holiday. Write it as a three-page story. The devil is truly in the details.
55. Catharsis
Write an email to your least favorite person. Send it to gof***yourself@around-around.com instead.
56. Living by Fiction
Take a day off. Dress in a disguise. Go about your day and write your experience.
57. Wings of Desire
Narrate your day from the perspective of your guardian angel, who also turns out to be kind-of a voyeur.
What was the last big argument you were involved in. Rewrite with all your well-thought-out rejoinders.
You’re best friend distrusts you. Why? 500 words.
60. Bodysnatcher
Recall a recent interaction with a stranger. Enter their body and live out their day in the first person.
Fictionalize the day when you were conceived. Do your research.
Recall your most embarassing moment. Write from the POV of your best friend at the time.
Imagine a world without violence. Write that world into your next story.
64. Blasphemy
Mock what you hold sacred in 500 words.
65. Loss
Read the last story you finished. Find the most common word (that isn’t he/she/the/it/etc.). Go into what you’re working on now and root it out.
What is your favorite appliance? Write the biography of its inventor without doing any research.
Write about your boss’ really sad life outside the office. Create a sympathetic character.
68. The Metaphysical R+J
Anthropomorphize an angel and a demon. Write them as a couple.
Co-opt your least favorite literary genre. What would you do differently?
70. The Printer. The Toaster.
Villainize a mundane object. Make that villainization the centerpiece of your next story.
Describe a despicable act. Sanitize it in a tale of morality. 500 Words.
Do you have a favorite joke? Expand it to five pages.
Take a character from your favorite book as a child. Where is that character now? Just as bitter and jaded as you?
74. Pontification
Ask a significant other what anecdote you break out most in small talk situations. Write it in ten pages using the tools of embellishment, dishonesty, and contradictions.
Call in sick. Write instead.
Who is your favorite secondary character ever? Think hard. Write a short story set in the days following their exit from the page.
Sit very still. Write the entire story in your mind. Do not put pen to paper or finger to key until you’ve conceived of it entirely.
Figure out which friend is having a birthday next and write a short story with them as the main character. Your deadline? Their birthday, of course.
What is the cornerstone of your identity? Remove it and write a character struggling without it.
80. Nightmare
Worst Possible Nightmare. Ruminate on those three words and then write.
Pull the rug out from under your strongest held belief. Write.
82. Impermanence
Alternate your writing tools from paragraph to paragraph—pen and paper, computer, typewriter, etc.
83. Ladders
Take a poem. Pretend it’s a ladder for your story. Use each line as a prompt.
84. Those Cool Kids
Have your character write a letter to the kids that had the cool drinks at school lunch.
Who gets the china?
First-person inevitable DUI story.
Write a story at the club while spending more money than you should.
Man vs. Future. 2001 words.
89. Bones of the Occupation
Write a skeleton list of what each character is doing in your story. What is their “work” in it?
90. Day Job Dreams
Your character just got the job that he’s always wanted. Your story starts 10 years later.
How badly does the dog get hurt during the accident with the lawn mower?
92. Talkies
Take a conversation in a story and write it as a movie script. Provide a lot of stage direction to the actors. Return it to prose.
What is your favorite novel? Write the main character’s horoscope in the newspaper the day before the novel begins.
Set a story in the land of your ancestors. Do your research. Let the research affect the plot.
95. Dirty Bedsheets
Strip your story down to its most important lines. It is now a poem.
96. Today's Kids
Tell us about sex ed movies in the age of sexting.
97. The Story Centipede
Write Story A. Its end becomes the beginning of Story B. Combine the stories to create Story C.
Reimagine your sex life as an erotic thriller with a consenting adult partner. Keep a diary.
99. Chores
Begin each day by retyping the best paragraph you’ve ever written.
